The crypto community is marking 17 years since Hal Finney posted the now-iconic message ‚ÄúRunning  $BTC,‚Äù a moment widely regarded as foundational to Bitcoin‚Äôs early history. In January 2009, Finney became one of the first people to run the Bitcoin software, helping validate the network in its earliest days.


Finney‚Äôs role went beyond symbolism. He was the recipient of the first-ever #Bitcoin transaction, sent by Satoshi Nakamoto, and actively engaged in technical discussions that shaped Bitcoin‚Äôs early development. His background in cryptography and quick response to the whitepaper cemented his status as a pioneer.


Over the years, speculation has occasionally linked Finney to Satoshi‚Äôs identity, though researchers and community members remain divided. Regardless, his legacy endures as a reminder that Bitcoin‚Äôs origins were built by individuals driven by curiosity, code, and conviction, not markets

Bitcoin's journey from $2 to $1,200 was a wild ride. It took around 4 years and 9 months for Bitcoin to reach $1,200 from $2.

Here's a rough breakdown:
- 2011: Bitcoin traded around $2-$10
- 2013: Bitcoin hit $1,000 in November
- 2013-2015: Bitcoin fluctuated, reaching $1,200 in November 2013, but then dropped
- 2016-2017: Bitcoin started gaining momentum, surpassing $1,000 again

To pinpoint:
- Bitcoin was around $2 in February 2011
- It reached $1,200 in November 2013

So, approximately 2 years and 9 months from $2 to $1,200.
